unnormalised: My uncle, Rajesh ji, a government school teacher in a small village near Patna, always struggled with finances. Every year, around budget time, he'd call me, his tech-savvy nephew in Bangalore, completely befuddled. "Beta," he'd say, his voice crackling over the phone, "what *is* all this 'fiscal deficit' and 'GDP growth rate' business? It’s all Hindi-English mixed, and I can’t make heads or tails of the darn financial report!"
normalised: My uncle, Rajesh ji, a government school teacher in a small village near Patna, always struggled with finances. Every year, around budget time, he'd call me, his tech-savvy nephew in Bangalore, completely befuddled. "Beta," he'd say, his voice crackling over the phone, "what *is* all this 'fiscal deficit' and 'G-D-P growth rate' business? It’s all Hindi-English mixed, and I can’t make heads or tails of the darn financial report!"

unnormalised: This year was no different. His call came just last week. "Rajesh!," he boomed, ever cheerful despite his financial woes. "The budget's out. Can you help me understand it? It says something about 'allocation for education up by 15%' but then I read the fine print and see a note saying 'subject to disbursement of outstanding dues amounting to Rs. 50,000 crore'. What does *that* even mean?"
normalised: This year was no different. His call came just last week. "Rajesh!," he boomed, ever cheerful despite his financial woes. "The budget's out. Can you help me understand it? It says something about 'allocation for education up by fifteen percent' but then I read the fine print and see a note saying 'subject to disbursement of outstanding dues amounting to rupee fifty thousand crore'. What does *that* even mean?"

unnormalised: I sighed, bracing myself. Explaining macroeconomics to someone who still used a feature phone was always a challenge. I started with the basics. "Uncle, a financial report is like your household budget. It shows where the govt plans to spend its money and how much it expects to earn."
normalised: I sighed, bracing myself. Explaining macroeconomics to someone who still used a feature phone was always a challenge. I started with the basics. "Uncle, a financial report is like your household budget. It shows where the government plans to spend its money and how much it expects to earn."

unnormalised: "Acha," he said, a little light dawning. "Like when I plan to buy groceries worth Rs. 2000 for the month?"
normalised: "Acha," he said, a little light dawning. "Like when I plan to buy groceries worth rupee two thousand for the month?"

unnormalised: "Exactly! And the financial report, particularly in the government budget, includes all sorts of details, from the planned spending on infrastructure projects like highways and dams, down to education and healthcare. For example, the railway budget in 2023 allocated approximately Rs. 2.4 lakh crore."
normalised: "Exactly! And the financial report, particularly in the government budget, includes all sorts of details, from the planned spending on infrastructure projects like highways and dams, down to education and healthcare. For example, the railway budget in two thousand twenty three allocated approximately rupee two point four lakh crore."

unnormalised: Then came the tricky part. "The 'fiscal deficit', uncle," I continued, "is like when you spend more than you earn. If the govt spends Rs. 100 but only earns Rs. 80, the deficit is Rs. 20." He understood that part pretty well, given his usual situation.
normalised: Then came the tricky part. "The 'fiscal deficit', uncle," I continued, "is like when you spend more than you earn. If the government spends rupee one hundred but only earns rupee eighty, the deficit is rupee twenty." He understood that part pretty well, given his usual situation.

unnormalised: "And GDP growth rate?" He prompted. "That sounds very fancy."
normalised: "And G-D-P growth rate?" He prompted. "That sounds very fancy."

unnormalised: "GDP is like the total income of the entire country. The growth rate is how much that income has increased compared to the previous year. The Economic Survey 2023-24 projected a GDP growth of 6.5%."
normalised: "G-D-P is like the total income of the entire country. The growth rate is how much that income has increased compared to the previous year. The Economic Survey two thousand twenty three to two thousand twenty four projected a G-D-P growth of six point five percent."

unnormalised: I could almost hear him scratching his head through the phone. "So, if the growth rate is good, everyone is getting richer?"
normalised: I could almost hear him scratching his head through the phone. "So, if the growth rate is good, everyone is getting richer?"

unnormalised: "In theory, yes. But it doesn't always translate that way on the ground, as you well know," I replied, thinking of his meager teacher's salary. "As for that clause about 'subject to disbursement', that means that the promised 15% increase in education funds will only happen *if* the government actually releases the Rs. 50,000 crore it already owes."
normalised: "In theory, yes. But it doesn't always translate that way on the ground, as you well know," I replied, thinking of his meager teacher's salary. "As for that clause about 'subject to disbursement', that means that the promised fifteen percent increase in education funds will only happen *if* the government actually releases the rupee fifty thousand crore it already owes."

unnormalised: "Ah, the old 'if'," he said with a knowing chuckle. "The same 'if' that keeps my pending arrears from 2010 still pending!" He then started asking questions about the actual report, how much was allocated to building toilets in schools this year (down 5% apparently, according to the summary I saw), and whether the tax rate on his provident fund would change this year (thankfully no change listed for that). These calls were taxing, no pun intended, but at least he felt more empowered to understand the financial reports that were ultimately about him and the people of India. I just wish the reports could be a little simpler to digest for the average person. Maybe then, the number "15" would really mean a 15% increase.
